intro: Syngonanthus umbellatus f. latifolius, commonly known as the broadleaf marsh hibiscus, is a variant of the marsh hibiscus native to wetland environments in South America. It is characterized by its broad, lance-shaped leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late summer and early fall. It thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils and is often found in marshes and along riverbanks. This subspecies is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological role in supporting local wildlife.
